def knotInsertion( self, ctrl_pts: numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating], knots_to_add: Iterable[Union[numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64], int]]) -> numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating]: 
751    def knotInsertion(
752        self, 
753        ctrl_pts: np.ndarray[np.floating], 
754        knots_to_add: Iterable[Union[np.ndarray[np.float64], int]]
755        ) -> np.ndarray[np.floating]:
756        """
757        Add knots to the B-spline while preserving its geometry.
758
759        This method performs knot insertion by adding new knots to each isoparametric dimension
760        and computing the new control points to maintain the exact same geometry. The method
761        modifies the `BSpline` object by updating its basis functions with the new knots.
762
763        Parameters
764        ----------
765        ctrl_pts : np.ndarray[np.floating]
766            Control points defining the B-spline geometry.
767            Shape: (`NPh`, n1, n2, ...) where:
768            - `NPh` is the dimension of the physical space
769            - ni is the number of control points in the i-th isoparametric dimension
770
771        knots_to_add : Iterable[Union[np.ndarray[np.floating], int]]
772            Refinement specification for each isoparametric dimension.
773            For each dimension, two formats are accepted:
774            1. `numpy.ndarray`: Array of knots to insert. These knots must lie within
775            the span of the existing knot vector.
776            2. `int`: Number of equally spaced knots to insert in each element.
777
778        Returns
779        -------
780        new_ctrl_pts : np.ndarray[np.floating]
781            New control points after knot insertion.
782            Shape: (`NPh`, m1, m2, ...) where mi ≥ ni is the new number of
783            control points in the i-th isoparametric dimension.
784
785        Notes
786        -----
787        - Knot insertion preserves the geometry and parameterization of the B-spline
788        - The number of new control points depends on the number and multiplicity of inserted knots
789        - When using integer input, knots are inserted with uniform spacing in each element
790        - The method modifies the basis functions but maintains `C^{p-m}` continuity,
791        where `p` is the degree and `m` is the multiplicity of the inserted knot
792
793        Examples
794        --------
795        Create a 2D quadratic B-spline and insert knots:
796        >>> degrees = [2, 2]
797        >>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
798        ...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
799        >>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
800        >>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 4)  # 3D control points
801
802        Insert specific knots in first dimension only:
803        >>> knots_to_add = [np.array([0.25, 0.75], dtype='float'),
804        ...                 np.array([], dtype='float')]
805        >>> new_ctrl_pts = spline.knotInsertion(ctrl_pts, knots_to_add)
806        >>> new_ctrl_pts.shape
807        (3, 6, 4)  # Two new control points added in first dimension
808        >>> spline.getKnots()[0]  # The knot vector is modified
809        array([0.  , 0.  , 0.  , 0.25, 0.5 , 0.75, 1.  , 1.  , 1.  ])
810
811        Insert two knots per element in both dimensions:
812        >>> new_ctrl_pts = spline.knotInsertion(new_ctrl_pts, [1, 1])
813        >>> new_ctrl_pts.shape
814        (3, 10, 6)  # Uniform refinement in both dimensions
815        >>> spline.getKnots()[0]  # The knot vectors are further modified
816        array([0.   , 0.   , 0.   , 0.125, 0.25 , 0.375, 0.5  , 0.625, 0.75 ,
817               0.875, 1.   , 1.   , 1.   ])
818        """
819        true_knots_to_add = []
820        for axis, knots_to_add_elem in enumerate(knots_to_add):
821            if isinstance(knots_to_add_elem, int): # It is a number of knots to add in each element
822                u_knot = np.unique(self.bases[axis].knot)
823                a, b = u_knot[:-1, None], u_knot[1:, None]
824                mu = np.linspace(0, 1, knots_to_add_elem + 1, endpoint=False)[None, 1:]
825                true_knots_to_add.append((a + (b - a)*mu).ravel())
826            else:
827                true_knots_to_add.append(knots_to_add_elem)
828        knots_to_add = true_knots_to_add
829        
830        pts_shape = np.empty(self.NPa, dtype='int')
831        D = None
832        for idx in range(self.NPa):
833            basis = self.bases[idx]
834            knots_to_add_elem = knots_to_add[idx]
835            D_elem = basis.knotInsertion(knots_to_add_elem)
836            pts_shape[idx] = D_elem.shape[0]
837            if D is None:
838                D = D_elem
839            else:
840                D = sps.kron(D, D_elem)
841        NPh = ctrl_pts.shape[0]
842        pts = (D @ ctrl_pts.reshape((NPh, -1)).T).T
843        ctrl_pts = pts.reshape((NPh, *pts_shape))
844        return ctrl_pts

Add knots to the B-spline while preserving its geometry.

This method performs knot insertion by adding new knots to each isoparametric dimension and computing the new control points to maintain the exact same geometry. The method modifies the BSpline object by updating its basis functions with the new knots.

Parameters
  • ctrl_pts (np.ndarray[np.floating]): Control points defining the B-spline geometry. Shape: (NPh, n1, n2, ...) where:
    • NPh is the dimension of the physical space
    • ni is the number of control points in the i-th isoparametric dimension
  • knots_to_add (Iterable[Union[np.ndarray[np.floating], int]]): Refinement specification for each isoparametric dimension. For each dimension, two formats are accepted:
    1. numpy.ndarray: Array of knots to insert. These knots must lie within the span of the existing knot vector.
    2. int: Number of equally spaced knots to insert in each element.
Returns
  • new_ctrl_pts (np.ndarray[np.floating]): New control points after knot insertion. Shape: (NPh, m1, m2, ...) where mi ≥ ni is the new number of control points in the i-th isoparametric dimension.
Notes
  • Knot insertion preserves the geometry and parameterization of the B-spline
  • The number of new control points depends on the number and multiplicity of inserted knots
  • When using integer input, knots are inserted with uniform spacing in each element
  • The method modifies the basis functions but maintains C^{p-m} continuity, where p is the degree and m is the multiplicity of the inserted knot
Examples

Create a 2D quadratic B-spline and insert knots:

>>> degrees = [2, 2]
>>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
>>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
>>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 4)  # 3D control points

Insert specific knots in first dimension only:

>>> knots_to_add = [np.array([0.25, 0.75], dtype='float'),
...                 np.array([], dtype='float')]
>>> new_ctrl_pts = spline.knotInsertion(ctrl_pts, knots_to_add)
>>> new_ctrl_pts.shape
(3, 6, 4)  # Two new control points added in first dimension
>>> spline.getKnots()[0]  # The knot vector is modified
array([0.  , 0.  , 0.  , 0.25, 0.5 , 0.75, 1.  , 1.  , 1.  ])

Insert two knots per element in both dimensions:

>>> new_ctrl_pts = spline.knotInsertion(new_ctrl_pts, [1, 1])
>>> new_ctrl_pts.shape
(3, 10, 6)  # Uniform refinement in both dimensions
>>> spline.getKnots()[0]  # The knot vectors are further modified
array([0.   , 0.   , 0.   , 0.125, 0.25 , 0.375, 0.5  , 0.625, 0.75 ,
       0.875, 1.   , 1.   , 1.   ])
def orderElevation( self, ctrl_pts: numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating], t: Iterable[int]) -> numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating]: 
846    def orderElevation(
847        self, 
848        ctrl_pts: np.ndarray[np.floating], 
849        t: Iterable[int]
850        ) -> np.ndarray[np.floating]:
851        """
852        Elevate the polynomial degree of the B-spline while preserving its geometry.
853
854        This method performs order elevation by increasing the polynomial degree of each
855        isoparametric dimension and computing the new control points to maintain the exact
856        same geometry. The method modifies the `BSpline` object by updating its basis
857        functions with the new degrees.
858
859        Parameters
860        ----------
861        ctrl_pts : np.ndarray[np.floating]
862            Control points defining the B-spline geometry.
863            Shape: (`NPh`, n1, n2, ...) where:
864            - `NPh` is the dimension of the physical space
865            - ni is the number of control points in the i-th isoparametric dimension
866
867        t : Iterable[int]
868            Degree elevation for each isoparametric dimension.
869            For each dimension i, the new degree will be `p_i + t_i` where `p_i`
870            is the current degree.
871
872        Returns
873        -------
874        new_ctrl_pts : np.ndarray[np.floating]
875            New control points after order elevation.
876            Shape: (`NPh`, m1, m2, ...) where mi ≥ ni is the new number of
877            control points in the i-th isoparametric dimension.
878
879        Notes
880        -----
881        - Order elevation preserves the geometry and parameterization of the B-spline
882        - The number of new control points depends on the current degree and number of 
883        elements
884        - The method modifies the `BSpline` object by updating its basis functions
885        - This operation is more computationally expensive than knot insertion
886
887        Examples
888        --------
889        Create a 2D quadratic B-spline and elevate its order:
890        >>> degrees = [2, 2]
891        >>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
892        ...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
893        >>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
894        >>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 4)  # 3D control points
895
896        Elevate order by 1 in first dimension only:
897        >>> t = [1, 0]  # Increase degree by 1 in first dimension
898        >>> new_ctrl_pts = spline.orderElevation(ctrl_pts, t)
899        >>> new_ctrl_pts.shape
900        (3, 6, 4)  # Two new control points added in first dimension (one per element)
901        >>> spline.getDegrees()  # The degrees are modified
902        array([3, 2])
903        """
904        pts_shape = np.empty(self.NPa, dtype='int')
905        STD = None
906        for idx in range(self.NPa):
907            basis = self.bases[idx]
908            t_basis = t[idx]
909            STD_elem = basis.orderElevation(t_basis)
910            pts_shape[idx] = STD_elem.shape[0]
911            if STD is None:
912                STD = STD_elem
913            else:
914                STD = sps.kron(STD, STD_elem)
915        NPh = ctrl_pts.shape[0]
916        pts = (STD @ ctrl_pts.reshape((NPh, -1)).T).T
917        ctrl_pts = pts.reshape((NPh, *pts_shape))
918        return ctrl_pts

Elevate the polynomial degree of the B-spline while preserving its geometry.

This method performs order elevation by increasing the polynomial degree of each isoparametric dimension and computing the new control points to maintain the exact same geometry. The method modifies the BSpline object by updating its basis functions with the new degrees.

Parameters
  • ctrl_pts (np.ndarray[np.floating]): Control points defining the B-spline geometry. Shape: (NPh, n1, n2, ...) where:
    • NPh is the dimension of the physical space
    • ni is the number of control points in the i-th isoparametric dimension
  • t (Iterable[int]): Degree elevation for each isoparametric dimension. For each dimension i, the new degree will be p_i + t_i where p_i is the current degree.
Returns
  • new_ctrl_pts (np.ndarray[np.floating]): New control points after order elevation. Shape: (NPh, m1, m2, ...) where mi ≥ ni is the new number of control points in the i-th isoparametric dimension.
Notes
  • Order elevation preserves the geometry and parameterization of the B-spline
  • The number of new control points depends on the current degree and number of elements
  • The method modifies the BSpline object by updating its basis functions
  • This operation is more computationally expensive than knot insertion
Examples

Create a 2D quadratic B-spline and elevate its order:

>>> degrees = [2, 2]
>>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
>>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
>>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 4)  # 3D control points

Elevate order by 1 in first dimension only:

>>> t = [1, 0]  # Increase degree by 1 in first dimension
>>> new_ctrl_pts = spline.orderElevation(ctrl_pts, t)
>>> new_ctrl_pts.shape
(3, 6, 4)  # Two new control points added in first dimension (one per element)
>>> spline.getDegrees()  # The degrees are modified
array([3, 2])
def greville_abscissa( self, return_weights: bool = False) -> Union[list[numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating]], tuple[list[numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating]], list[numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating]]]]: 
920    def greville_abscissa(
921        self, 
922        return_weights: bool=False
923        ) -> Union[list[np.ndarray[np.floating]], tuple[list[np.ndarray[np.floating]], list[np.ndarray[np.floating]]]]:
924        """
925        Compute the Greville abscissa and optionally their weights for each isoparametric dimension.
926
927        The Greville abscissa can be interpreted as the "position" of the control points in the 
928        isoparametric space. They are often used as interpolation points for B-splines.
929
930        Parameters
931        ----------
932        return_weights : bool, optional
933            If `True`, also returns the weights (span lengths) of each basis function.
934            By default, False.
935
936        Returns
937        -------
938        greville : list[np.ndarray[np.floating]]
939            List containing the Greville abscissa for each isoparametric dimension.
940            The list has length `NPa`, where each element is an array of size `n + 1`,
941            `n` being the last index of the basis functions in that dimension.
942
943        weights : list[np.ndarray[np.floating]], optional
944            Only returned if `return_weights` is `True`.
945            List containing the weights for each isoparametric dimension.
946            The list has length `NPa`, where each element is an array containing
947            the span length of each basis function.
948
949        Notes
950        -----
951        - For a curve (1D), returns [`xi` abscissa]
952        - For a surface (2D), returns [`xi` abscissa, `eta` abscissa]
953        - For a volume (3D), returns [`xi` abscissa, `eta` abscissa, `zeta` abscissa]
954        - The Greville abscissa are computed as averages of `p` consecutive knots
955        - The weights represent the size of the support of each basis function
956        - The number of abscissa in each dimension equals the number of control points
957
958        Examples
959        --------
960        Compute Greville abscissa for a 2D B-spline:
961        >>> degrees = [2, 2]
962        >>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
963        ...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
964        >>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
965        >>> greville = spline.greville_abscissa()
966        >>> greville[0]  # xi coordinates
967        array([0.  , 0.25, 0.75, 1.  ])
968        >>> greville[1]  # eta coordinates
969        array([0. , 0.5, 1. ])
970
971        Compute both abscissa and weights:
972        >>> greville, weights = spline.greville_abscissa(return_weights=True)
973        >>> weights[0]  # weights for xi direction
974        array([0.5, 1. , 1. , 0.5])
975        """
976        greville = []
977        weights = []
978        for idx in range(self.NPa):
979            basis = self.bases[idx]
980            p = basis.p
981            knot = basis.knot
982            greville.append(np.convolve(knot[1:-1], np.ones(p, dtype=int), 'valid')/p)
983            weights.append(knot[(p+1):] - knot[:-(p+1)])
984        if return_weights:
985            return greville, weights
986        return greville

Compute the Greville abscissa and optionally their weights for each isoparametric dimension.

The Greville abscissa can be interpreted as the "position" of the control points in the isoparametric space. They are often used as interpolation points for B-splines.

Parameters
  • return_weights (bool, optional): If True, also returns the weights (span lengths) of each basis function. By default, False.
Returns
  • greville (list[np.ndarray[np.floating]]): List containing the Greville abscissa for each isoparametric dimension. The list has length NPa, where each element is an array of size n + 1, n being the last index of the basis functions in that dimension.
  • weights (list[np.ndarray[np.floating]], optional): Only returned if return_weights is True. List containing the weights for each isoparametric dimension. The list has length NPa, where each element is an array containing the span length of each basis function.
Notes
  • For a curve (1D), returns [xi abscissa]
  • For a surface (2D), returns [xi abscissa, eta abscissa]
  • For a volume (3D), returns [xi abscissa, eta abscissa, zeta abscissa]
  • The Greville abscissa are computed as averages of p consecutive knots
  • The weights represent the size of the support of each basis function
  • The number of abscissa in each dimension equals the number of control points
Examples

Compute Greville abscissa for a 2D B-spline:

>>> degrees = [2, 2]
>>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
>>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
>>> greville = spline.greville_abscissa()
>>> greville[0]  # xi coordinates
array([0.  , 0.25, 0.75, 1.  ])
>>> greville[1]  # eta coordinates
array([0. , 0.5, 1. ])

Compute both abscissa and weights:

>>> greville, weights = spline.greville_abscissa(return_weights=True)
>>> weights[0]  # weights for xi direction
array([0.5, 1. , 1. , 0.5])
def make_control_poly_meshes( self, ctrl_pts: numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating], n_eval_per_elem: Union[int, Iterable[int]] = 10, n_step: int = 1, fields: dict = {}, XI: Optional[tuple[numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating], ...]] = None, paraview_sizes: dict = {}) -> list[meshio._mesh.Mesh]: 
 988    def make_control_poly_meshes(self, 
 989                                 ctrl_pts: np.ndarray[np.floating], 
 990                                 n_eval_per_elem: Union[int, Iterable[int]]=10, 
 991                                 n_step: int=1, 
 992                                 fields: dict={}, 
 993                                 XI: Union[None, tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...]]=None, 
 994                                 paraview_sizes: dict={}) -> list[io.Mesh]:
 995        """
 996        Create meshes containing all the data needed to plot the control polygon of the B-spline.
 997
 998        This method generates a list of `io.Mesh` objects representing the control mesh 
 999        (polygonal connectivity) of the B-spline, suitable for visualization (e.g. in Paraview). 
1000        It supports time-dependent fields and arbitrary dimension.
1001
1002        Parameters
1003        ----------
1004        ctrl_pts : np.ndarray[np.floating]
1005            Array of control points of the B-spline, with shape 
1006            (`NPh`, number of elements for dim 1, ..., number of elements for dim `NPa`), 
1007            where `NPh` is the physical space dimension and `NPa` is the dimension of the 
1008            isoparametric space.
1009        n_step : int, optional
1010            Number of time steps to plot. By default, 1.
1011        n_eval_per_elem : Union[int, Iterable[int]], optional
1012            Number of evaluation points per element for each isoparametric dimension.
1013            By default, 10.
1014            - If an `int` is provided, the same number is used for all dimensions.
1015            - If an `Iterable` is provided, each value corresponds to a different dimension.
1016        n_step : int, optional
1017            Number of time steps to plot. By default, 1.
1018        fields : dict, optional
1019            Dictionary of fields to plot at each time step. Keys are field names. Values can be:
1020            - a `function` taking (`BSpline` spline, `tuple` of `np.ndarray[np.floating]` XI) and
1021            returning a `np.ndarray[np.floating]` of shape (`n_step`, number of combinations of XI, field size),
1022            - a `np.ndarray[np.floating]` defined **on the control points**, of shape (`n_step`, field size, *`ctrl_pts.shape[1:]`),
1023            which is then interpolated using the B-spline basis functions,
1024            - a `np.ndarray[np.floating]` defined **on the evaluation grid**, of shape (`n_step`, field size, *grid shape),
1025            where `grid shape` matches the discretization provided by XI or `n_eval_per_elem`.
1026            In this case, the field is interpolated in physical space using `scipy.interpolate.griddata`.
1027        XI : tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...], optional
1028            Parametric coordinates at which to evaluate the B-spline and fields.
1029            If not `None`, overrides the `n_eval_per_elem` parameter.
1030            If `None`, a regular grid is generated according to `n_eval_per_elem`.
1031        paraview_sizes: dict, optionnal
1032            The fields present in this `dict` are overrided by `np.NaN`s.
1033            The keys must be the fields names and the values must be the fields sizes for paraview.
1034            By default, {}.
1035
1036        Returns
1037        -------
1038        list[io.Mesh]
1039            List of `io.Mesh` objects, one for each time step, containing the control mesh geometry 
1040            and associated fields.
1041
1042        Notes
1043        -----
1044        - The control mesh is constructed by connecting control points along each isoparametric direction.
1045        - Fields can be provided either as functions evaluated at the Greville abscissae, or as arrays defined on the 
1046        control points or on a regular parametric grid (in which case they are interpolated at the Greville abscissae).
1047        - The first axis of the field array or function output corresponds to the time step, even if there is only one.
1048        - The method is compatible with B-splines of arbitrary dimension.
1049
1050        Examples
1051        --------
1052        >>> degrees = [2, 2]
1053        >>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
1054        ...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
1055        >>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
1056        >>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 3)  # 3D control points for a 2D surface
1057        >>> meshes = spline.make_control_poly_meshes(ctrl_pts)
1058        >>> mesh = meshes[0]
1059        """
1060        if XI is None:
1061            XI = self.linspace(n_eval_per_elem)
1062        interp_points = self(ctrl_pts, XI).reshape((3, -1)).T
1063        shape = [xi.size for xi in XI]
1064        NXI = np.prod(shape)
1065        NPh = ctrl_pts.shape[0]
1066        lines = np.empty((0, 2), dtype='int')
1067        size = np.prod(ctrl_pts.shape[1:])
1068        inds = np.arange(size).reshape(ctrl_pts.shape[1:])
1069        for idx in range(self.NPa):
1070            rng = np.arange(inds.shape[idx])
1071            lines = np.append(lines, 
1072                              np.concatenate((np.expand_dims(np.take(inds, rng[ :-1], axis=idx), axis=-1), 
1073                                              np.expand_dims(np.take(inds, rng[1:  ], axis=idx), axis=-1)), 
1074                                             axis=-1).reshape((-1, 2)), 
1075                             axis=0)
1076        cells = {'line': lines}
1077        points = np.moveaxis(ctrl_pts, 0, -1).reshape((-1, NPh))
1078        greville = tuple(self.greville_abscissa())
1079        n = self.getNbFunc()
1080        point_data = {}
1081        for key, value in fields.items():
1082            if key in paraview_sizes:
1083                point_data[key] = np.full((n_step, n, paraview_sizes[key]), np.NAN)
1084            elif callable(value):
1085                point_data[key] = value(self, greville)
1086            else:
1087                value = np.asarray(value)
1088                if value.ndim>=2 and value.shape[-self.NPa:]==tuple(ctrl_pts.shape[1:]):
1089                    point_data[key] = value.reshape((n_step, -1, n)).transpose(0, 2, 1)
1090                elif value.ndim>=2 and value.shape[-self.NPa:]==tuple(shape):
1091                    paraview_size = value.shape[1]
1092                    interp_field = griddata(interp_points, value.reshape((n_step*paraview_size, NXI)).T, points, method='linear')
1093                    point_data[key] = interp_field.reshape((n, n_step, paraview_size)).transpose(1, 0, 2)
1094                else:
1095                    raise ValueError(f"Field {key} shape {value.shape} not understood.")
1096        # make meshes
1097        meshes = []
1098        for i in range(n_step):
1099            point_data_step = {}
1100            for key, value in point_data.items():
1101                point_data_step[key] = value[i]
1102            mesh = io.Mesh(points, cells, point_data_step) # type: ignore
1103            meshes.append(mesh)
1104
1105        return meshes

Create meshes containing all the data needed to plot the control polygon of the B-spline.

This method generates a list of io.Mesh objects representing the control mesh (polygonal connectivity) of the B-spline, suitable for visualization (e.g. in Paraview). It supports time-dependent fields and arbitrary dimension.

Parameters
  • ctrl_pts (np.ndarray[np.floating]): Array of control points of the B-spline, with shape (NPh, number of elements for dim 1, ..., number of elements for dim NPa), where NPh is the physical space dimension and NPa is the dimension of the isoparametric space.
  • n_step (int, optional): Number of time steps to plot. By default, 1.
  • n_eval_per_elem (Union[int, Iterable[int]], optional): Number of evaluation points per element for each isoparametric dimension. By default, 10.
    • If an int is provided, the same number is used for all dimensions.
    • If an Iterable is provided, each value corresponds to a different dimension.
  • n_step (int, optional): Number of time steps to plot. By default, 1.
  • fields (dict, optional): Dictionary of fields to plot at each time step. Keys are field names. Values can be:
    • a function taking (BSpline spline, tuple of np.ndarray[np.floating] XI) and returning a np.ndarray[np.floating] of shape (n_step, number of combinations of XI, field size),
    • a np.ndarray[np.floating] defined on the control points, of shape (n_step, field size, *ctrl_pts.shape[1:]), which is then interpolated using the B-spline basis functions,
    • a np.ndarray[np.floating] defined on the evaluation grid, of shape (n_step, field size, *grid shape), where grid shape matches the discretization provided by XI or n_eval_per_elem. In this case, the field is interpolated in physical space using scipy.interpolate.griddata.
  • XI (tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...], optional): Parametric coordinates at which to evaluate the B-spline and fields. If not None, overrides the n_eval_per_elem parameter. If None, a regular grid is generated according to n_eval_per_elem.
  • paraview_sizes (dict, optionnal): The fields present in this dict are overrided by np.NaNs. The keys must be the fields names and the values must be the fields sizes for paraview. By default, {}.
Returns
  • list[io.Mesh]: List of io.Mesh objects, one for each time step, containing the control mesh geometry and associated fields.
Notes
  • The control mesh is constructed by connecting control points along each isoparametric direction.
  • Fields can be provided either as functions evaluated at the Greville abscissae, or as arrays defined on the control points or on a regular parametric grid (in which case they are interpolated at the Greville abscissae).
  • The first axis of the field array or function output corresponds to the time step, even if there is only one.
  • The method is compatible with B-splines of arbitrary dimension.
Examples
>>> degrees = [2, 2]
>>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
>>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
>>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 3)  # 3D control points for a 2D surface
>>> meshes = spline.make_control_poly_meshes(ctrl_pts)
>>> mesh = meshes[0]
def make_elem_separator_meshes( self, ctrl_pts: numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating], n_eval_per_elem: Union[int, Iterable[int]] = 10, n_step: int = 1, fields: dict = {}, XI: Optional[tuple[numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating], ...]] = None, paraview_sizes: dict = {}) -> list[meshio._mesh.Mesh]: 
1107    def make_elem_separator_meshes(self, 
1108                                   ctrl_pts: np.ndarray[np.floating], 
1109                                   n_eval_per_elem: Union[int, Iterable[int]]=10, 
1110                                   n_step: int=1, 
1111                                   fields: dict={}, 
1112                                   XI: Union[None, tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...]]=None, 
1113                                   paraview_sizes: dict={}) -> list[io.Mesh]:
1114        """
1115        Create meshes representing the boundaries of every element in the B-spline for visualization.
1116
1117        This method generates a list of `io.Mesh` objects containing the geometry and optional fields
1118        needed to plot the limits (borders) of all elements from the isoparametric space of the B-spline.
1119        Supports time-dependent fields and arbitrary dimension.
1120
1121        Parameters
1122        ----------
1123        ctrl_pts : np.ndarray[np.floating]
1124            Array of control points of the B-spline, with shape
1125            (`NPh`, number of elements for dim 1, ..., number of elements for dim `NPa`),
1126            where `NPh` is the physical space dimension and `NPa` is the dimension of the
1127            isoparametric space.
1128        n_eval_per_elem : Union[int, Iterable[int]], optional
1129            Number of evaluation points per element for each isoparametric dimension.
1130            By default, 10.
1131            - If an `int` is provided, the same number is used for all dimensions.
1132            - If an `Iterable` is provided, each value corresponds to a different dimension.
1133        n_step : int, optional
1134            Number of time steps to plot. By default, 1.
1135        fields : dict, optional
1136            Dictionary of fields to plot at each time step. Keys are field names. Values can be:
1137            - a `function` taking (`BSpline` spline, `tuple` of `np.ndarray[np.floating]` XI) and
1138            returning a `np.ndarray[np.floating]` of shape (`n_step`, number of combinations of XI, field size),
1139            - a `np.ndarray[np.floating]` defined **on the control points**, of shape (`n_step`, field size, *`ctrl_pts.shape[1:]`),
1140            which is then interpolated using the B-spline basis functions,
1141            - a `np.ndarray[np.floating]` defined **on the evaluation grid**, of shape (`n_step`, field size, *grid shape),
1142            where `grid shape` matches the discretization provided by XI or `n_eval_per_elem`.
1143            In this case, the field is interpolated in physical space using `scipy.interpolate.griddata`.
1144        XI : tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...], optional
1145            Parametric coordinates at which to evaluate the B-spline and fields.
1146            If not `None`, overrides the `n_eval_per_elem` parameter.
1147            If `None`, a regular grid is generated according to `n_eval_per_elem`.
1148        paraview_sizes: dict, optionnal
1149            The fields present in this `dict` are overrided by `np.NaN`s.
1150            The keys must be the fields names and the values must be the fields sizes for paraview.
1151            By default, {}.
1152
1153        Returns
1154        -------
1155        list[io.Mesh]
1156            List of `io.Mesh` objects, one for each time step, containing the element boundary geometry
1157            and associated fields.
1158
1159        Notes
1160        -----
1161        - The element boundary mesh is constructed by connecting points along the unique knot values
1162        in each isoparametric direction, outlining the limits of each element.
1163        - Fields can be provided either as callable functions, as arrays defined on the control points,
1164        or as arrays already defined on a regular evaluation grid.
1165        - When fields are defined on a grid, they are interpolated in the physical space using
1166        `scipy.interpolate.griddata` with linear interpolation.
1167        - The first axis of the field array or function output corresponds to the time step, even if there is only one.
1168        - The method supports B-splines of arbitrary dimension.
1169
1170        Examples
1171        --------
1172        >>> degrees = [2, 2]
1173        >>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
1174        ...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
1175        >>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
1176        >>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 3)  # 3D control points for a 2D surface
1177        >>> meshes = spline.make_elem_separator_meshes(ctrl_pts)
1178        >>> mesh = meshes[0]
1179        """
1180        if XI is None:
1181            XI = self.linspace(n_eval_per_elem)
1182        interp_points = self(ctrl_pts, XI).reshape((3, -1)).T
1183        shape = [xi.size for xi in XI]
1184        NXI = np.prod(shape)
1185        NPh = ctrl_pts.shape[0]
1186        knots_uniq = []
1187        shape_uniq = []
1188        for basis in self.bases:
1189            knot = basis.knot
1190            knot_uniq = np.unique(knot[np.logical_and(knot>=0, knot<=1)])
1191            knots_uniq.append(knot_uniq)
1192            shape_uniq.append(knot_uniq.size)
1193        points = None
1194        point_data = {key: None for key in fields}
1195        lines = None
1196        Size = 0
1197        n = self.getNbFunc()
1198        for idx in range(self.NPa):
1199            basis = self.bases[idx]
1200            knot_uniq = knots_uniq[idx]
1201            n_eval = n_eval_per_elem[idx]
1202            couples = np.concatenate((np.expand_dims(knot_uniq[ :-1], axis=0), 
1203                                      np.expand_dims(knot_uniq[1:  ], axis=0)), 
1204                                     axis=0).reshape((2, -1)).T
1205            for a, b in couples:
1206                lin =  np.linspace(a, b, n_eval)
1207                inner_XI = tuple(knots_uniq[:idx] + [lin] + knots_uniq[(idx+1):])
1208                inner_shape = shape_uniq[:idx] + [lin.size] + shape_uniq[(idx+1):]
1209                size = np.prod(inner_shape)
1210                N = self.DN(inner_XI, [0]*self.NPa) # type: ignore
1211                pts = N @ ctrl_pts.reshape((NPh, -1)).T
1212                points = pts if points is None else np.vstack((points, pts))
1213                for key, value in fields.items():
1214                    if key in paraview_sizes:
1215                        to_store = np.full((n_step, size, paraview_sizes[key]), np.NAN)
1216                    elif callable(value):
1217                        to_store = value(self, inner_XI)
1218                    else:
1219                        value = np.asarray(value)
1220                        if value.ndim>=2 and value.shape[-self.NPa:]==tuple(ctrl_pts.shape[1:]):
1221                            paraview_size = value.shape[1]
1222                            arr = value.reshape((n_step, paraview_size, n)).reshape((n_step*paraview_size, n))
1223                            to_store = (arr @ N.T).reshape((n_step, paraview_size, -1)).transpose(0, 2, 1)
1224                        elif value.ndim>=2 and value.shape[-self.NPa:]==tuple(shape):
1225                            paraview_size = value.shape[1]
1226                            interp_field = griddata(interp_points, value.reshape((n_step*paraview_size, NXI)).T, pts, method='linear')
1227                            to_store = interp_field.reshape((pts.shape[0], n_step, paraview_size)).transpose(1, 0, 2)
1228                        else:
1229                            raise ValueError(f"Field {key} shape {value.shape} not understood.")
1230                    if point_data[key] is None:
1231                        point_data[key] = to_store
1232                    else:
1233                        point_data[key] = np.concatenate((point_data[key], to_store), axis=1) # type: ignore
1234                lns = Size + np.arange(size).reshape(inner_shape)
1235                lns = np.moveaxis(lns, idx, 0).reshape((inner_shape[idx], -1))
1236                lns = np.concatenate((np.expand_dims(lns[ :-1], axis=-1), 
1237                                      np.expand_dims(lns[1:  ], axis=-1)), 
1238                                     axis=-1).reshape((-1, 2))
1239                lines = lns if lines is None else np.vstack((lines, lns))
1240                Size += size
1241        cells = {'line': lines}
1242        # make meshes
1243        meshes = []
1244        for i in range(n_step):
1245            point_data_step = {}
1246            for key, value in point_data.items():
1247                point_data_step[key] = value[i] # type: ignore
1248            mesh = io.Mesh(points, cells, point_data_step) # type: ignore
1249            meshes.append(mesh)
1250        
1251        return meshes

Create meshes representing the boundaries of every element in the B-spline for visualization.

This method generates a list of io.Mesh objects containing the geometry and optional fields needed to plot the limits (borders) of all elements from the isoparametric space of the B-spline. Supports time-dependent fields and arbitrary dimension.

Parameters
  • ctrl_pts (np.ndarray[np.floating]): Array of control points of the B-spline, with shape (NPh, number of elements for dim 1, ..., number of elements for dim NPa), where NPh is the physical space dimension and NPa is the dimension of the isoparametric space.
  • n_eval_per_elem (Union[int, Iterable[int]], optional): Number of evaluation points per element for each isoparametric dimension. By default, 10.
    • If an int is provided, the same number is used for all dimensions.
    • If an Iterable is provided, each value corresponds to a different dimension.
  • n_step (int, optional): Number of time steps to plot. By default, 1.
  • fields (dict, optional): Dictionary of fields to plot at each time step. Keys are field names. Values can be:
    • a function taking (BSpline spline, tuple of np.ndarray[np.floating] XI) and returning a np.ndarray[np.floating] of shape (n_step, number of combinations of XI, field size),
    • a np.ndarray[np.floating] defined on the control points, of shape (n_step, field size, *ctrl_pts.shape[1:]), which is then interpolated using the B-spline basis functions,
    • a np.ndarray[np.floating] defined on the evaluation grid, of shape (n_step, field size, *grid shape), where grid shape matches the discretization provided by XI or n_eval_per_elem. In this case, the field is interpolated in physical space using scipy.interpolate.griddata.
  • XI (tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...], optional): Parametric coordinates at which to evaluate the B-spline and fields. If not None, overrides the n_eval_per_elem parameter. If None, a regular grid is generated according to n_eval_per_elem.
  • paraview_sizes (dict, optionnal): The fields present in this dict are overrided by np.NaNs. The keys must be the fields names and the values must be the fields sizes for paraview. By default, {}.
Returns
  • list[io.Mesh]: List of io.Mesh objects, one for each time step, containing the element boundary geometry and associated fields.
Notes
  • The element boundary mesh is constructed by connecting points along the unique knot values in each isoparametric direction, outlining the limits of each element.
  • Fields can be provided either as callable functions, as arrays defined on the control points, or as arrays already defined on a regular evaluation grid.
  • When fields are defined on a grid, they are interpolated in the physical space using scipy.interpolate.griddata with linear interpolation.
  • The first axis of the field array or function output corresponds to the time step, even if there is only one.
  • The method supports B-splines of arbitrary dimension.
Examples
>>> degrees = [2, 2]
>>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
>>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
>>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 3)  # 3D control points for a 2D surface
>>> meshes = spline.make_elem_separator_meshes(ctrl_pts)
>>> mesh = meshes[0]
def make_elements_interior_meshes( self, ctrl_pts: numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating], n_eval_per_elem: Union[int, Iterable[int]] = 10, n_step: int = 1, fields: dict = {}, XI: Optional[tuple[numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating], ...]] = None) -> list[meshio._mesh.Mesh]: 
1253    def make_elements_interior_meshes(self, 
1254                                      ctrl_pts: np.ndarray[np.floating], 
1255                                      n_eval_per_elem: Union[int, Iterable[int]]=10, 
1256                                      n_step: int=1, 
1257                                      fields: dict={}, 
1258                                      XI: Union[None, tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...]]=None) -> list[io.Mesh]:
1259        """
1260        Create meshes representing the interior of each element in the B-spline.
1261
1262        This method generates a list of `io.Mesh` objects containing the geometry and optional fields
1263        for the interior of all elements, suitable for visualization (e.g., in ParaView). Supports
1264        time-dependent fields and arbitrary dimension.
1265
1266        Parameters
1267        ----------
1268        ctrl_pts : np.ndarray[np.floating]
1269            Array of control points of the B-spline, with shape
1270            (`NPh`, number of points for dim 1, ..., number of points for dim `NPa`),
1271            where `NPh` is the physical space dimension and `NPa` is the dimension of
1272            the isoparametric space.
1273        n_eval_per_elem : Union[int, Iterable[int]], optional
1274            Number of evaluation points per element for each isoparametric dimension.
1275            By default, 10.
1276            - If an `int` is provided, the same number is used for all dimensions.
1277            - If an `Iterable` is provided, each value corresponds to a different dimension.
1278        n_step : int, optional
1279            Number of time steps to plot. By default, 1.
1280        fields : dict, optional
1281            Dictionary of fields to plot at each time step. Keys are field names. Values can be:
1282            - a `function` taking (`BSpline` spline, `tuple` of `np.ndarray[np.floating]` XI) and
1283            returning a `np.ndarray[np.floating]` of shape (`n_step`, number of combinations of XI, field size),
1284            - a `np.ndarray[np.floating]` defined **on the control points**, of shape (`n_step`, field size, *`ctrl_pts.shape[1:]`),
1285            in which case it is interpolated using the B-spline basis functions,
1286            - a `np.ndarray[np.floating]` defined **directly on the evaluation grid**, of shape (`n_step`, field size, *grid shape),
1287            where `grid shape` is the shape of the discretization XI (i.e., number of points along each parametric axis).
1288            By default, `{}` (no fields).
1289        XI : tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...], optional
1290            Parametric coordinates at which to evaluate the B-spline and fields.
1291            If not `None`, overrides the `n_eval_per_elem` parameter.
1292            If `None`, a regular grid is generated according to `n_eval_per_elem`.
1293
1294        Returns
1295        -------
1296        list[io.Mesh]
1297            List of `io.Mesh` objects, one for each time step, containing the element interior geometry
1298            and associated fields.
1299
1300        Notes
1301        -----
1302        - The interior mesh is constructed by evaluating the B-spline at a regular grid of points
1303        in the isoparametric space, with connectivity corresponding to lines (1D), quads (2D), or
1304        hexahedra (3D).
1305        - Fields can be provided either as arrays (on control points or on the discretization grid) or as functions.
1306        - Arrays given on control points are automatically interpolated using the B-spline basis functions.
1307        - Arrays already given on the evaluation grid are used directly without interpolation.
1308        - The first axis of the field array or function output must correspond to the time step, even if there is only one.
1309        - The method is compatible with B-splines of arbitrary dimension.
1310
1311        Examples
1312        --------
1313        >>> degrees = [2, 2]
1314        >>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
1315        ...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
1316        >>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
1317        >>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 3)  # 3D control points for a 2D surface
1318        >>> # Field given on control points (needs interpolation)
1319        >>> field_on_ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(1, 1, 4, 3)
1320        >>> # Field given directly on the evaluation grid (no interpolation)
1321        >>> field_on_grid = np.random.rand(1, 1, 10, 10)
1322        >>> meshes = spline.make_elements_interior_meshes(
1323        ...     ctrl_pts,
1324        ...     fields={'temperature': field_on_ctrl_pts, 'pressure': field_on_grid}
1325        ...     XI= # TODO
1326        ... )
1327        >>> mesh = meshes[0]
1328        """
1329        if XI is None:
1330            XI = self.linspace(n_eval_per_elem)
1331        # make points
1332        N = self.DN(XI)
1333        NPh = ctrl_pts.shape[0]
1334        points = N @ ctrl_pts.reshape((NPh, -1)).T
1335        # make connectivity
1336        elements = {2: "line", 4: "quad", 8: "hexahedron"}
1337        shape = [xi.size for xi in XI]
1338        NXI = np.prod(shape)
1339        inds = np.arange(NXI).reshape(shape)
1340        for idx in range(self.NPa):
1341            rng = np.arange(inds.shape[idx])
1342            inds = np.concatenate((np.expand_dims(np.take(inds, rng[ :-1], axis=idx), axis=-1), 
1343                                   np.expand_dims(np.take(inds, rng[1:  ], axis=idx), axis=-1)), axis=-1)
1344        if self.NPa>=2:
1345            for i in np.ndindex(*inds.shape[:-2]):
1346                inds[i] = [[inds[i+(0, 0)], inds[i+(0, 1)]], [inds[i+(1, 1)], inds[i+(1, 0)]]]
1347        inds = inds.reshape((*inds.shape[:self.NPa], -1))
1348        inds = inds.reshape((-1, inds.shape[-1]))
1349        cells = {elements[inds.shape[-1]]: inds}
1350        # make fields
1351        n = self.getNbFunc()
1352        point_data = {}
1353        for key, value in fields.items():
1354            if callable(value):
1355                point_data[key] = value(self, XI)
1356            else:
1357                value = np.asarray(value)
1358                if value.ndim>=2 and value.shape[-self.NPa:]==tuple(ctrl_pts.shape[1:]):
1359                    # Field given on control points: interpolate with basis functions
1360                    paraview_size = value.shape[1]
1361                    arr = value.reshape((n_step * paraview_size, n))
1362                    point_data[key] = (arr @ N.T).reshape((n_step, paraview_size, NXI)).transpose(0, 2, 1)
1363                elif value.ndim>=2 and value.shape[-self.NPa:]==tuple(shape):
1364                    # Field already given on discretization grid
1365                    paraview_size = value.shape[1]
1366                    point_data[key] = value.reshape((n_step, paraview_size, NXI)).transpose(0, 2, 1)
1367                else:
1368                    raise ValueError(f"Field {key} shape {value.shape} not understood.")
1369        # make meshes
1370        meshes = []
1371        for i in range(n_step):
1372            point_data_step = {}
1373            for key, value in point_data.items():
1374                point_data_step[key] = value[i]
1375            mesh = io.Mesh(points, cells, point_data_step) # type: ignore
1376            meshes.append(mesh)
1377            
1378        return meshes

Create meshes representing the interior of each element in the B-spline.

This method generates a list of io.Mesh objects containing the geometry and optional fields for the interior of all elements, suitable for visualization (e.g., in ParaView). Supports time-dependent fields and arbitrary dimension.

Parameters
  • ctrl_pts (np.ndarray[np.floating]): Array of control points of the B-spline, with shape (NPh, number of points for dim 1, ..., number of points for dim NPa), where NPh is the physical space dimension and NPa is the dimension of the isoparametric space.
  • n_eval_per_elem (Union[int, Iterable[int]], optional): Number of evaluation points per element for each isoparametric dimension. By default, 10.
    • If an int is provided, the same number is used for all dimensions.
    • If an Iterable is provided, each value corresponds to a different dimension.
  • n_step (int, optional): Number of time steps to plot. By default, 1.
  • fields (dict, optional): Dictionary of fields to plot at each time step. Keys are field names. Values can be:
    • a function taking (BSpline spline, tuple of np.ndarray[np.floating] XI) and returning a np.ndarray[np.floating] of shape (n_step, number of combinations of XI, field size),
    • a np.ndarray[np.floating] defined on the control points, of shape (n_step, field size, *ctrl_pts.shape[1:]), in which case it is interpolated using the B-spline basis functions,
    • a np.ndarray[np.floating] defined directly on the evaluation grid, of shape (n_step, field size, *grid shape), where grid shape is the shape of the discretization XI (i.e., number of points along each parametric axis). By default, {} (no fields).
  • XI (tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...], optional): Parametric coordinates at which to evaluate the B-spline and fields. If not None, overrides the n_eval_per_elem parameter. If None, a regular grid is generated according to n_eval_per_elem.
Returns
  • list[io.Mesh]: List of io.Mesh objects, one for each time step, containing the element interior geometry and associated fields.
Notes
  • The interior mesh is constructed by evaluating the B-spline at a regular grid of points in the isoparametric space, with connectivity corresponding to lines (1D), quads (2D), or hexahedra (3D).
  • Fields can be provided either as arrays (on control points or on the discretization grid) or as functions.
  • Arrays given on control points are automatically interpolated using the B-spline basis functions.
  • Arrays already given on the evaluation grid are used directly without interpolation.
  • The first axis of the field array or function output must correspond to the time step, even if there is only one.
  • The method is compatible with B-splines of arbitrary dimension.
Examples
>>> degrees = [2, 2]
>>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
>>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
>>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 3)  # 3D control points for a 2D surface
>>> # Field given on control points (needs interpolation)
>>> field_on_ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(1, 1, 4, 3)
>>> # Field given directly on the evaluation grid (no interpolation)
>>> field_on_grid = np.random.rand(1, 1, 10, 10)
>>> meshes = spline.make_elements_interior_meshes(
...     ctrl_pts,
...     fields={'temperature': field_on_ctrl_pts, 'pressure': field_on_grid}
...     XI= # TODO
... )
>>> mesh = meshes[0]
def saveParaview( self, ctrl_pts: numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating], path: str, name: str, n_step: int = 1, n_eval_per_elem: Union[int, Iterable[int]] = 10, fields: Optional[dict] = None, XI: Optional[tuple[numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating], ...]] = None, groups: Optional[dict[str, dict[str, Union[str, int]]]] = None, make_pvd: bool = True, verbose: bool = True, fields_on_interior_only: Union[bool, Literal['auto'], list[str]] = 'auto') -> dict[str, dict[str, typing.Union[str, int]]]: 
1380    def saveParaview(
1381        self, 
1382        ctrl_pts: np.ndarray[np.floating], 
1383        path: str, 
1384        name: str, 
1385        n_step: int=1, 
1386        n_eval_per_elem: Union[int, Iterable[int]]=10, 
1387        fields: Union[dict, None]=None, 
1388        XI: Union[None, tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...]]=None, 
1389        groups: Union[dict[str, dict[str, Union[str, int]]], None]=None, 
1390        make_pvd: bool=True, 
1391        verbose: bool=True, 
1392        fields_on_interior_only: Union[bool, Literal['auto'], list[str]]='auto'
1393        ) -> dict[str, dict[str, Union[str, int]]]:
1394        """
1395        Save B-spline visualization data as Paraview files.
1396
1397        This method creates three types of visualization files:
1398        - Interior mesh showing the B-spline surface/volume
1399        - Element borders showing the mesh structure
1400        - Control points mesh showing the control structure
1401        
1402        All files are saved in VTU format with an optional PVD file to group them.
1403
1404        Parameters
1405        ----------
1406        ctrl_pts : np.ndarray[np.floating]
1407            Control points defining the B-spline geometry.
1408            Shape: (`NPh`, n1, n2, ...) where:
1409            - `NPh` is the dimension of the physical space
1410            - ni is the number of control points in the i-th isoparametric dimension
1411
1412        path : str
1413            Directory path where the PV files will be saved
1414
1415        name : str
1416            Base name for the output files
1417
1418        n_step : int, optional
1419            Number of time steps to save. By default, 1.
1420
1421        n_eval_per_elem : Union[int, Iterable[int]], optional
1422            Number of evaluation points per element for each isoparametric dimension.
1423            By default, 10.
1424            - If an `int` is provided, the same number is used for all dimensions.
1425            - If an `Iterable` is provided, each value corresponds to a different dimension.
1426
1427        fields : Union[dict, None], optional
1428            Fields to visualize at each time step. Dictionary format:
1429            {
1430                "field_name": `field_value`
1431            }
1432            where `field_value` can be either:
1433            
1434            1. A numpy array with shape (`n_step`, `field_size`, `*ctrl_pts.shape[1:]`) where:
1435            - `n_step`: Number of time steps
1436            - `field_size`: Size of the field at each point (1 for scalar, 3 for vector)
1437            - `*ctrl_pts.shape[1:]`: Same shape as control points (excluding `NPh`)
1438            
1439            2. A numpy array with shape (`n_step`, `field_size`, `*grid_shape`) where:
1440            - `n_step`: Number of time steps
1441            - `field_size`: Size of the field at each point (1 for scalar, 3 for vector)
1442            - `*grid_shape`: Shape of the evaluation grid (number of points along each isoparametric axis)
1443            
1444            3. A function that computes field values (`np.ndarray[np.floating]`) at given 
1445            points from the `BSpline` instance and `XI`, the tuple of arrays containing evaluation 
1446            points for each dimension (`tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...]`).
1447            The result should be an array of shape (`n_step`, `n_points`, `field_size`) where:
1448            - `n_step`: Number of time steps
1449            - `n_points`: Number of evaluation points (n_xi × n_eta × ...)
1450            - `field_size`: Size of the field at each point (1 for scalar, 3 for vector)
1451            
1452            By default, None.
1453        
1454        XI : tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...], optional
1455            Parametric coordinates at which to evaluate the B-spline and fields.
1456            If not `None`, overrides the `n_eval_per_elem` parameter.
1457            If `None`, a regular grid is generated according to `n_eval_per_elem`.
1458
1459        groups : Union[dict[str, dict[str, Union[str, int]]], None], optional
1460            Nested dictionary specifying file groups for PVD organization. Format:
1461            {
1462                "group_name": {
1463                    "ext": str,     # File extension (e.g., "vtu")
1464                    "npart": int,   # Number of parts in the group
1465                    "nstep": int    # Number of timesteps
1466                }
1467            }
1468            The method automatically creates/updates three groups:
1469            - "interior": For the B-spline surface/volume mesh
1470            - "elements_borders": For the element boundary mesh
1471            - "control_points": For the control point mesh
1472            
1473            If provided, existing groups are updated; if None, these groups are created.
1474            By default, None.
1475
1476        make_pvd : bool, optional
1477            Whether to create a PVD file grouping all VTU files. By default, True.
1478
1479        verbose : bool, optional
1480            Whether to print progress information. By default, True.
1481
1482        fields_on_interior_only: Union[bool, Literal['auto'], list[str]], optionnal
1483            Whether to include fields only on the interior mesh (`True`), on all meshes (`False`),
1484            or on specified field names.
1485            If set to `'auto'`, fields named `'u'`, `'U'`, `'displacement'` or `'displ'` 
1486            are included on all meshes while others are only included on the interior mesh.
1487            By default, 'auto'.
1488
1489        Returns
1490        -------
1491        groups : dict[str, dict[str, Union[str, int]]]
1492            Updated groups dictionary with information about saved files.
1493
1494        Notes
1495        -----
1496        - Creates three types of VTU files for each time step:
1497            - {name}_interior_{part}_{step}.vtu
1498            - {name}_elements_borders_{part}_{step}.vtu
1499            - {name}_control_points_{part}_{step}.vtu
1500        - If `make_pvd=True`, creates a PVD file named {name}.pvd
1501        - Fields can be visualized as scalars or vectors in Paraview
1502        - The method supports time-dependent visualization through `n_step`
1503
1504        Examples
1505        --------
1506        Save a 2D B-spline visualization:
1507        >>> degrees = [2, 2]
1508        >>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
1509        ...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
1510        >>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
1511        >>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 4)  # 3D control points
1512        >>> spline.saveParaview(ctrl_pts, "./output", "bspline")
1513
1514        Save with a custom field:
1515        >>> def displacement(spline, XI):
1516        ...     # Compute displacement field
1517        ...     return np.random.rand(1, np.prod([x.size for x in XI]), 3)
1518        >>> fields = {"displacement": displacement}
1519        >>> spline.saveParaview(ctrl_pts, "./output", "bspline", fields=fields)
1520        """
1521        
1522        if type(n_eval_per_elem) is int:
1523            n_eval_per_elem = [n_eval_per_elem]*self.NPa
1524        
1525        if fields is None:
1526            fields = {}
1527        
1528        if groups is None:
1529            groups = {}
1530        
1531        interior = "interior"
1532        if interior in groups:
1533            groups[interior]["npart"] += 1
1534        else:
1535            groups[interior] = {"ext": "vtu", "npart": 1, "nstep": n_step}
1536        elements_borders = "elements_borders"
1537        if elements_borders in groups:
1538            groups[elements_borders]["npart"] += 1
1539        else:
1540            groups[elements_borders] = {"ext": "vtu", "npart": 1, "nstep": n_step}
1541        control_points = "control_points"
1542        if control_points in groups:
1543            groups[control_points]["npart"] += 1
1544        else:
1545            groups[control_points] = {"ext": "vtu", "npart": 1, "nstep": n_step}
1546        
1547        paraview_sizes = {}
1548        if fields_on_interior_only is True:
1549            for key, value in fields.items():
1550                if callable(value):
1551                    paraview_sizes[key] = value(self, np.zeros((self.NPa, 1))).shape[2]
1552                else:
1553                    paraview_sizes[key] = value.shape[1]
1554        elif fields_on_interior_only is False:
1555            pass
1556        elif fields_on_interior_only=='auto':
1557            for key, value in fields.items():
1558                if key not in ['u', 'U', 'displacement', 'displ']:
1559                    if callable(value):
1560                        paraview_sizes[key] = value(self, np.zeros((self.NPa, 1))).shape[2]
1561                    else:
1562                        paraview_sizes[key] = value.shape[1]
1563        else:
1564            for key in fields_on_interior_only:
1565                value = fields[key]
1566                if callable(value):
1567                    paraview_sizes[key] = value(self, np.zeros((self.NPa, 1))).shape[2]
1568                else:
1569                    paraview_sizes[key] = value.shape[1]
1570                
1571        meshes = self.make_elements_interior_meshes(ctrl_pts, n_eval_per_elem, n_step, fields, XI)
1572        prefix = os.path.join(path, f"{name}_{interior}_{groups[interior]['npart'] - 1}")
1573        for time_step, mesh in enumerate(meshes):
1574            mesh.write(f"{prefix}_{time_step}.vtu")
1575        if verbose:
1576            print(interior, "done")
1577
1578        meshes = self.make_elem_separator_meshes(ctrl_pts, n_eval_per_elem, n_step, fields, XI, paraview_sizes)
1579        prefix = os.path.join(path, f"{name}_{elements_borders}_{groups[elements_borders]['npart'] - 1}")
1580        for time_step, mesh in enumerate(meshes):
1581            mesh.write(f"{prefix}_{time_step}.vtu")
1582        if verbose:
1583            print(elements_borders, "done")
1584
1585        meshes = self.make_control_poly_meshes(ctrl_pts, n_eval_per_elem, n_step, fields, XI, paraview_sizes)
1586        prefix = os.path.join(path, f"{name}_{control_points}_{groups[control_points]['npart'] - 1}")
1587        for time_step, mesh in enumerate(meshes):
1588            mesh.write(f"{prefix}_{time_step}.vtu")
1589        if verbose:
1590            print(control_points, "done")
1591        
1592        if make_pvd:
1593            writePVD(os.path.join(path, name), groups)
1594        
1595        return groups

Save B-spline visualization data as Paraview files.

This method creates three types of visualization files:

  • Interior mesh showing the B-spline surface/volume
  • Element borders showing the mesh structure
  • Control points mesh showing the control structure

All files are saved in VTU format with an optional PVD file to group them.

Parameters
  • ctrl_pts (np.ndarray[np.floating]): Control points defining the B-spline geometry. Shape: (NPh, n1, n2, ...) where:
    • NPh is the dimension of the physical space
    • ni is the number of control points in the i-th isoparametric dimension
  • path (str): Directory path where the PV files will be saved
  • name (str): Base name for the output files
  • n_step (int, optional): Number of time steps to save. By default, 1.
  • n_eval_per_elem (Union[int, Iterable[int]], optional): Number of evaluation points per element for each isoparametric dimension. By default, 10.
    • If an int is provided, the same number is used for all dimensions.
    • If an Iterable is provided, each value corresponds to a different dimension.

  • fields (Union[dict, None], optional): Fields to visualize at each time step. Dictionary format: { "field_name": field_value } where field_value can be either:

    1. A numpy array with shape (n_step, field_size, *ctrl_pts.shape[1:]) where:
    • n_step: Number of time steps
    • field_size: Size of the field at each point (1 for scalar, 3 for vector)
    • *ctrl_pts.shape[1:]: Same shape as control points (excluding NPh)
    1. A numpy array with shape (n_step, field_size, *grid_shape) where:
    • n_step: Number of time steps
    • field_size: Size of the field at each point (1 for scalar, 3 for vector)
    • *grid_shape: Shape of the evaluation grid (number of points along each isoparametric axis)
    1. A function that computes field values (np.ndarray[np.floating]) at given points from the BSpline instance and XI, the tuple of arrays containing evaluation points for each dimension (tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...]). The result should be an array of shape (n_step, n_points, field_size) where:
    • n_step: Number of time steps
    • n_points: Number of evaluation points (n_xi × n_eta × ...)
    • field_size: Size of the field at each point (1 for scalar, 3 for vector)

    By default, None.

  • XI (tuple[np.ndarray[np.floating], ...], optional): Parametric coordinates at which to evaluate the B-spline and fields. If not None, overrides the n_eval_per_elem parameter. If None, a regular grid is generated according to n_eval_per_elem.

  • groups (Union[dict[str, dict[str, Union[str, int]]], None], optional): Nested dictionary specifying file groups for PVD organization. Format: { "group_name": { "ext": str, # File extension (e.g., "vtu") "npart": int, # Number of parts in the group "nstep": int # Number of timesteps } } The method automatically creates/updates three groups:

    • "interior": For the B-spline surface/volume mesh
    • "elements_borders": For the element boundary mesh
    • "control_points": For the control point mesh

    If provided, existing groups are updated; if None, these groups are created. By default, None.

  • make_pvd (bool, optional): Whether to create a PVD file grouping all VTU files. By default, True.
  • verbose (bool, optional): Whether to print progress information. By default, True.
  • fields_on_interior_only (Union[bool, Literal['auto'], list[str]], optionnal): Whether to include fields only on the interior mesh (True), on all meshes (False), or on specified field names. If set to 'auto', fields named 'u', 'U', 'displacement' or 'displ' are included on all meshes while others are only included on the interior mesh. By default, 'auto'.
Returns
  • groups (dict[str, dict[str, Union[str, int]]]): Updated groups dictionary with information about saved files.
Notes
  • Creates three types of VTU files for each time step:
    • {name}_interior_{part}_{step}.vtu
    • {name}_elements_borders_{part}_{step}.vtu
    • {name}_control_points_{part}_{step}.vtu
  • If make_pvd=True, creates a PVD file named {name}.pvd
  • Fields can be visualized as scalars or vectors in Paraview
  • The method supports time-dependent visualization through n_step
Examples

Save a 2D B-spline visualization:

>>> degrees = [2, 2]
>>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 0.5, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
>>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
>>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 4, 4)  # 3D control points
>>> spline.saveParaview(ctrl_pts, "./output", "bspline")

Save with a custom field:

>>> def displacement(spline, XI):
...     # Compute displacement field
...     return np.random.rand(1, np.prod([x.size for x in XI]), 3)
>>> fields = {"displacement": displacement}
>>> spline.saveParaview(ctrl_pts, "./output", "bspline", fields=fields)
def getGeomdl(self, ctrl_pts): 
1597    def getGeomdl(self, ctrl_pts):
1598        try:
1599            from geomdl import BSpline as geomdlBS
1600        except:
1601            raise 
1602        if self.NPa==1:
1603            curve = geomdlBS.Curve()
1604            curve.degree = self.bases[0].p
1605            curve.ctrl_pts = ctrl_pts.T.tolist()
1606            curve.knotvector = self.bases[0].knot
1607            return curve
1608        elif self.NPa==2:
1609            surf = geomdlBS.Surface()
1610            surf.degree_u = self.bases[0].p
1611            surf.degree_v = self.bases[1].p
1612            surf.ctrl_pts2d = ctrl_pts.transpose((1, 2, 0)).tolist()
1613            surf.knotvector_u = self.bases[0].knot
1614            surf.knotvector_v = self.bases[1].knot
1615            return surf
1616        elif self.NPa==3:
1617            vol = geomdlBS.Volume()
1618            vol.degree_u = self.bases[0].p
1619            vol.degree_v = self.bases[1].p
1620            vol.degree_w = self.bases[2].p
1621            vol.cpsize = ctrl_pts.shape[1:]
1622            # ctrl_pts format (zeta, xi, eta)
1623            vol.ctrl_pts = ctrl_pts.transpose(3, 1, 2, 0).reshape((-1, ctrl_pts.shape[0])).tolist()
1624            vol.knotvector_u = self.bases[0].knot
1625            vol.knotvector_v = self.bases[1].knot
1626            vol.knotvector_w = self.bases[2].knot
1627            return vol
1628        else:
1629            raise NotImplementedError("Can only export curves, sufaces or volumes !")
def plotMPL( self, ctrl_pts: numpy.ndarray[numpy.floating], n_eval_per_elem: Union[int, Iterable[int]] = 10, ax: Optional[matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes] = None, ctrl_color: str = '#1b9e77', interior_color: str = '#7570b3', elem_color: str = '#666666', border_color: str = '#d95f02', language: Union[Literal['english'], Literal['français']] = 'english'): 
1634    def plotMPL(
1635        self, 
1636        ctrl_pts: np.ndarray[np.floating], 
1637        n_eval_per_elem: Union[int, Iterable[int]]=10, 
1638        ax: Union[mpl.axes.Axes, None]=None, 
1639        ctrl_color: str='#1b9e77', 
1640        interior_color: str='#7570b3', 
1641        elem_color: str='#666666', 
1642        border_color: str='#d95f02', 
1643        language: Union[Literal["english"], Literal["français"]]="english"
1644        ):
1645        """
1646        Plot the B-spline using Matplotlib.
1647
1648        Creates a visualization of the B-spline geometry showing the control mesh,
1649        B-spline surface/curve, element borders, and patch borders. Supports plotting
1650        1D curves and 2D surfaces in 2D space, and 2D surfaces and 3D volumes in 3D space.
1651
1652        Parameters
1653        ----------
1654        ctrl_pts : np.ndarray[np.floating]
1655            Control points defining the B-spline geometry.
1656            Shape: (NPh, n1, n2, ...) where:
1657            - NPh is the dimension of the physical space (2 or 3)
1658            - ni is the number of control points in the i-th isoparametric dimension
1659
1660        n_eval_per_elem : Union[int, Iterable[int]], optional
1661            Number of evaluation points per element for visualizing the B-spline.
1662            Can be specified as:
1663            - Single integer: Same number for all dimensions
1664            - Iterable of integers: Different numbers for each dimension
1665            By default, 10.
1666
1667        ax : Union[mpl.axes.Axes, None], optional
1668            Matplotlib axes for plotting. If None, creates a new figure and axes.
1669            For 3D visualizations, must be a 3D axes if provided (created with 
1670            `projection='3d'`).
1671            Default is None (creates new axes).
1672
1673        ctrl_color : str, optional
1674            Color for the control mesh visualization:
1675            - Applied to control points (markers)
1676            - Applied to control mesh lines
1677            Default is '#1b9e77' (green).
1678
1679        interior_color : str, optional
1680            Color for the B-spline geometry:
1681            - For curves: Line color
1682            - For surfaces: Face color (with transparency)
1683            - For volumes: Face color of boundary surfaces (with transparency)
1684            Default is '#7570b3' (purple).
1685
1686        elem_color : str, optional
1687            Color for element boundary visualization:
1688            - Shows internal mesh structure
1689            - Helps visualize knot locations
1690            Default is '#666666' (gray).
1691
1692        border_color : str, optional
1693            Color for patch boundary visualization:
1694            - Outlines the entire B-spline patch
1695            - Helps distinguish patch edges
1696            Default is '#d95f02' (orange).
1697        
1698        language: str, optional
1699            Language for the plot labels. Can be 'english' or 'français'.
1700            Default is 'english'.
1701
1702        Notes
1703        -----
1704        Visualization components:
1705        - Control mesh: Shows control points and their connections
1706        - B-spline: Shows the actual curve/surface/volume
1707        - Element borders: Shows the boundaries between elements
1708        - Patch borders: Shows the outer boundaries of the B-spline
1709
1710        Supported configurations:
1711        - 1D B-spline in 2D space (curve)
1712        - 2D B-spline in 2D space (surface)
1713        - 2D B-spline in 3D space (surface)
1714        - 3D B-spline in 3D space (volume)
1715
1716        For 3D visualization:
1717        - Surfaces are shown with transparency
1718        - Volume visualization shows the faces with transparency
1719        - View angle is automatically set for surfaces based on surface normal
1720
1721        Examples
1722        --------
1723        Plot a 2D curve in 2D space:
1724        >>> degrees = [2]
1725        >>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
1726        >>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
1727        >>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(2, 3)  # 2D control points
1728        >>> spline.plotMPL(ctrl_pts)
1729
1730        Plot a 2D surface in 3D space:
1731        >>> degrees = [2, 2]
1732        >>> knots = [np.array([0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float'),
1733        ...          np.array([0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1], dtype='float')]
1734        >>> spline = BSpline(degrees, knots)
1735        >>> ctrl_pts = np.random.rand(3, 3, 3)  # 3D control points
1736        >>> spline.plotMPL(ctrl_pts)
1737
1738        Plot on existing axes with custom colors:
1739        >>> fig = plt.figure()
1740        >>> ax = fig.add_subplot(projection='3d')
1741        >>> spline.plotMPL(ctrl_pts, ax=ax, ctrl_color='red', interior_color='blue')
1742        """
1743        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
1744        from matplotlib.collections import LineCollection
1745        from matplotlib.patches import Polygon
1746        from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.art3d import Line3DCollection
1747        from matplotlib import lines
1748        if language=="english":
1749            ctrl_mesh = "Control mesh"
1750            elems_bord = "Elements borders"
1751            b_spline = "B-spline"
1752            b_spline_patch = "B-spline patch"
1753            patch_bord = "Patch borders"
1754        elif language=="français":
1755            ctrl_mesh = "Maillage de contrôle"
1756            elems_bord = "Frontières inter-éléments"
1757            b_spline = "B-spline"
1758            b_spline_patch = "Patch B-spline"
1759            patch_bord = "Frontières inter-patchs"
1760        else:
1761            raise NotImplementedError(f"Can't understand language '{language}'. Try 'english' or 'français'.")
1762        NPh = ctrl_pts.shape[0]
1763        fig = plt.figure() if ax is None else ax.get_figure()
1764        if NPh==2:
1765            ax = fig.add_subplot() if ax is None else ax
1766            if self.NPa==1:
1767                ax.plot(ctrl_pts[0], ctrl_pts[1], marker="o", c=ctrl_color, label=ctrl_mesh, zorder=0)
1768                xi, = self.linspace(n_eval_per_elem=n_eval_per_elem)
1769                x, y = self.__call__(ctrl_pts, [xi])
1770                ax.plot(x, y, c=interior_color, label=b_spline, zorder=1)
1771                xi_elem, = self.linspace(n_eval_per_elem=1)
1772                x_elem, y_elem = self.__call__(ctrl_pts, [xi_elem])
1773                ax.scatter(x_elem, y_elem, marker='*', c=elem_color, label=elems_bord, zorder=2) # type: ignore
1774            elif self.NPa==2:
1775                xi, eta = self.linspace(n_eval_per_elem=n_eval_per_elem)
1776                xi_elem, eta_elem = self.linspace(n_eval_per_elem=1)
1777                x_xi, y_xi = self.__call__(ctrl_pts, [xi_elem, eta])
1778                x_eta, y_eta = self.__call__(ctrl_pts, [xi, eta_elem])
1779                x_pol = np.hstack((x_xi[ 0, :: 1], x_eta[:: 1, -1], x_xi[-1, ::-1], x_eta[::-1,  0]))
1780                y_pol = np.hstack((y_xi[ 0, :: 1], y_eta[:: 1, -1], y_xi[-1, ::-1], y_eta[::-1,  0]))
1781                xy_pol = np.hstack((x_pol[:, None], y_pol[:, None]))
1782                ax.add_patch(Polygon(xy_pol, fill=True, edgecolor=None, facecolor=interior_color, alpha=0.5, label=b_spline_patch, zorder=0)) # type: ignore
1783                ax.plot(ctrl_pts[0, 0, 0], ctrl_pts[1, 0, 0], marker="o", c=ctrl_color, label=ctrl_mesh, zorder=1, ms=plt.rcParams['lines.markersize']/np.sqrt(2))
1784                ax.add_collection(LineCollection(ctrl_pts.transpose(1, 2, 0), colors=ctrl_color, zorder=1)) # type: ignore
1785                ax.add_collection(LineCollection(ctrl_pts.transpose(2, 1, 0), colors=ctrl_color, zorder=1)) # type: ignore
1786                ax.scatter(ctrl_pts[0].ravel(), ctrl_pts[1].ravel(), marker="o", c=ctrl_color, zorder=1, s=0.5*plt.rcParams['lines.markersize']**2) # type: ignore
1787                ax.plot(x_xi[0, 0], y_xi[0, 0], linestyle="-", c=elem_color, label=elems_bord, zorder=2)
1788                ax.add_collection(LineCollection(np.array([x_xi, y_xi]).transpose(1, 2, 0)[1:-1], colors=elem_color, zorder=2)) # type: ignore
1789                ax.add_collection(LineCollection(np.array([x_eta, y_eta]).transpose(2, 1, 0)[1:-1], colors=elem_color, zorder=2)) # type: ignore
1790                ax.add_patch(Polygon(xy_pol, lw=1.25*plt.rcParams['lines.linewidth'], fill=False, edgecolor=border_color, label=patch_bord, zorder=2)) # type: ignore
1791            else:
1792                raise ValueError(f"Can't plot a {self.NPa}D shape in a 2D space.")
1793            ax.legend()
1794            ax.set_aspect(1)
1795        elif NPh==3:
1796            ax = fig.add_subplot(projection='3d') if ax is None else ax
1797            if self.NPa==1:
1798                pass
1799            elif self.NPa==2:
1800                xi, eta = self.linspace(n_eval_per_elem=n_eval_per_elem)
1801                xi_elem, eta_elem = self.linspace(n_eval_per_elem=1)
1802                x, y, z = self.__call__(ctrl_pts, [xi, eta])
1803                x_xi, y_xi, z_xi = self.__call__(ctrl_pts, [xi_elem, eta])
1804                x_eta, y_eta, z_eta = self.__call__(ctrl_pts, [xi, eta_elem])
1805                ax.plot_surface(x, y, z, rcount=1, ccount=1, edgecolor=None, facecolor=interior_color, alpha=0.5)
1806                ax.plot_wireframe(ctrl_pts[0], ctrl_pts[1], ctrl_pts[2], color=ctrl_color, zorder=2)
1807                ax.scatter(ctrl_pts[0], ctrl_pts[1], ctrl_pts[2], color=ctrl_color, zorder=2)
